header.title: Pomba Gira and the Quimbanda of Mbùmba Nzila

central_thesis: This book aims to provide a deep, nuanced understanding of Pomba Gira, presenting her not as a simplistic 'devil's wife' or 'prostitute,' but as a complex, evolving, and multifaceted spirit embodying female power, passion, and wisdom. Drawing from African, European, and indigenous Brazilian traditions, Pomba Gira is depicted as a potent guide for human evolution and self-realization, who challenges conventional morality and encourages practitioners to confront their true selves for spiritual growth and mastery over life's passions.

structure_content.summary: The author introduces his work as a corrective to misunderstandings of Quimbanda, stemming from his earlier book 'Kiumbanda'. He presents Pomba Gira as a dynamic, 'skin-shedding' spirit that reveals herself across cultures and times, acting as a challenging yet ultimately benevolent guide for self-discovery and the understanding of the human condition.

This section frames Quimbanda as a 'black art' involving Exu and Pomba Gira, primarily serving the oppressed through 'socio-magical skin-shedding.' It traces Quimbanda's historical roots through 'Macumba' and 'Magia Negra,' emphasizing its strong Congo legacy, the role of *nkulu* (soul/ancestors), and the diversity of its contemporary forms influenced by various esoteric and spiritualist currents. The author stresses that these spirits reflect human passions rather than external 'hell'.

structure_content.chapter_title: II Saravá Pomba Gira – An Ouverture
structure_content.summary: Pomba Gira is celebrated as a manifestation of female virtue and power, embodying figures from history and myth such as Mary Magdalene, Venus, Maria Padilha, Lilith, and Cleopatra. These figures represent the erotic, revolutionary, and wise aspects of womanhood. The section discusses Pomba Gira's association with various 'kingdoms' (Ocean, Cemetery, Cabaret, Streets) and her role in defying male dominance and social conventions, emphasizing her free and shameless nature.

structure_content.chapter_title: III The Snake at the Erotic Crossroad
structure_content.summary: This chapter explores the etymological and symbolic origins of Pomba Gira, linking her name to 'whirling pigeon' and a corruption of 'Mbùmba Nzila' (mystery/secret of the crossing), connecting her to fertility, serpentine spirits (*mbùmba*), Venus, and ancient Kongo cosmology (kisimbi spirits). She is presented as the 'serpent of fertility' at the crossroad, akin to Kundalini, and sharing attributes with the Drakaina/Python as a chthonic visionary source and guardian of hidden knowledge.

The essence of Quimbanda is presented as the 'serpents engaged in love-play,' emphasizing its pragmatic and adaptive nature rather than rigid dogma. It discusses the balance required when working with these powerful, often fierce, spirits, especially concerning fire, tobacco, and alcohol. The chapter introduces the concept of Pomba Gira's soul manifesting through specific plants (nightshades like Belladonna, Malevolence, Devil's Thorn, Wolf Apple, Pepper, Tobacco, Henbane, Womandrake, Aconite, Fig, Dog's Mercury, Poppy, Rue), highlighting their magical and medicinal properties related to healing, protection, and malefica.

structure_content.chapter_title: V A Retinue of Passion and Blood
structure_content.summary: Pomba Gira's retinue is explored as diverse manifestations of passion, linked to the Nine Kingdoms and the Yorubá concept of *ajé* (Lady of the Birds of Night). The *ajé* are spirits of social agitation, witchcraft, and emotions, reflected in Pomba Gira's colors (black, red, white) and elemental connections. The chapter discusses the idea of 'new' Pomba Giras evolving from disincarnated spirits, and the unique transmigration of women with strong emotional affinities upon death into Pomba Giras, particularly in relation to Exu Calunga (ancestral memory in abysmal waters).

This chapter delves into Pomba Gira Sete Maridos/Sete Porteiras, highlighting her unpredictability and power. She is seen as the source of Quimbanda's power, with male partners being 'borrowed.' The author emphasizes the transactional nature of workings with her, stressing honesty and the understanding that she challenges practitioners to master their wild passions. The concept of spirits evolving from 'pagan' to 'baptized' to 'crowned' is introduced, mirroring human spiritual maturation. The importance of establishing a stable 'tronco' (altar) for consistent work is explained, along with warnings about obsession and inappropriate demands.

This section details the 'Kingdoms' of Quimbanda as concentrations of sulfur and enchantment spirits, linking Pomba Gira's fiery nature to alchemy (sulfur as celestial ferment). It outlines the Seven Lines of Quimbanda (Malei, Souls, Cemetery, Nagô, Mossorubi, Caboclos Quimbandeiros, Mixed Line) with their respective Exu rulers, and the Nine Queendoms of Pomba Gira (Cemetery, Crossroads, Sepulchres, Lyre, Streets, Wilderness, Soul, Oceanshore, Calunga), specifying their rulers, attributes, and auspicious days for workings. It also introduces Exu Ganga as a protective spirit and gatekeeper.

A comprehensive catalog of various Pomba Giras is presented, including Maria Padilha, Pomba Gira Rainha, and many others, detailing their specific domains, preferences (colors, offerings, days), and unique characteristics. Each entry includes illustrative *pontos cantados* (songs) and *pontos riscados* (spirit sigils). The author discusses the historical and mythical backgrounds of these spirits, their syncretic associations with demonesses and saints, and practical workings for various intentions, from love bindings and protection to breaking negative spells and influencing adversaries. The emphasis is on understanding their individual natures and respecting their power.

The concluding chapter summarizes Pomba Gira as the 'root of all' and the 'burning bush,' representing infinite knowledge and the unity of good and bad. It reiterates her role in supporting women's freedom and self-assertion, encouraging practitioners to embrace challenges and understand her gospel of love and freedom. The author reflects on his role as scribe, hoping the book contributes to a deeper appreciation of Pomba Gira as a muse and guide.

A concise list of key terms used in Quimbanda and the book, with definitions ranging from ritual objects (Alguidar, Assentamento, Patuá, Pemba) and offerings (Amací, Dendé, Ebó, Padê, Marafo) to spirit categories (Caboclo, Egun, Kiumba, Malandro, Preto velho), ritual actions (Amarrar, Despacho, Gira, Tabaque), and leadership roles (Cambono/a, Tatá, Yayá).

A list of academic and spiritual texts referenced or related to the author's research, providing sources for further study on Afro-Brazilian religions, spiritism, magic, and related occult traditions.

key_concepts.definition: A complex and multifaceted spirit in Quimbanda, embodying female power, passion, wisdom, and erotic strength. She is seen as a 'skin-shedding' power, capable of manifesting in diverse forms and challenging individuals to confront their inner truths. Often associated with crossroads, night, and the domain of passions. Her role transcends simplistic good/evil dichotomies, acting as a guide for spiritual evolution and self-realization.

An Afro-Brazilian religion considered a 'black art' or 'left hand' of Umbanda, focused on working with Exu and Pomba Gira. It is characterized by its pragmatic approach, adaptability, and the use of spirits (often departed souls or 'eguns') for various purposes, including healing, protection, attack, and personal growth. It has strong roots in Congolese traditions and incorporates elements of European demonology and indigenous practices. The cult is seen as constantly evolving and adapting to social needs.

The male counterpart to Pomba Gira in Quimbanda, often referred to as the 'King Snake.' Exu represents force, aggression, and the domain of the social world and male aspects of human passion. He is considered the gatekeeper of the kingdoms and works in conjunction with Pomba Gira. In Quimbanda, he is often syncretized with diabolical figures, though this is viewed as an absorption of iconography rather than inherent evil.

An earlier, generic term for nocturnal magical practice in Brazil, often used pejoratively to mean 'black magic' or African sorcery. It refers to the crossroads of indigenous, European, and African sorcerous practices from which Quimbanda emerged. The term is also linked to Kikongo 'mayumba' meaning a magical working that ignites insanity.
Spirit signatures or designs drawn with sacred chalk (*pemba*) that replicate a spirit's nature, used to call them into manifestation and to provide stability to workings.
Songs designed to praise or manifest spirits, used during rituals to invoke and connect with specific Exus and Pomba Giras.

A physical 'seat of power' or altar, typically a small house or structure, established as the foundation of a terreiro (temple) for Exu and Pomba Gira. It serves to provide stability for the medium, ward off intrusive spirits, and secure the working space. It can also refer to the main spirit supporting the Tatá.
A spirit vessel, usually a terracotta jar, created to house and give a resting place for spirits, especially Pomba Gira and Exu, allowing them to manifest and exert their influence.

Specific domains or concentrations of spirits where Pomba Gira manifests, each with distinct attributes, rulers, and types of work. Examples include the Kingdom of the Cemetery, Crossroads, Sepulchres, Lyre, Streets, Wilderness, Soul, Oceanshore, and Calunga.

A beloved Pomba Gira, patroness of the poor and widows, associated with charity and kindness. Her legend highlights resilience through suffering, ultimately leading to spiritual power. Offerings to her often involve flowers and simple, heartfelt gifts.

One of the most famous Pomba Giras, an archetypical European witch figure known for efficacy in rituals and swift desire fulfillment. She represents the independent woman, spanning aristocratic and rustic aspects, and is said to have multiple manifestations across various kingdoms and 'roads'.

A term with multiple meanings in Quimbanda, primarily referring to the cemetery or the ancestral ocean. Pomba Giras associated with Calunga deal with the dead, the mysteries of absence, and deep emotions, often appearing as mermaids or sea creatures.

A class of trickster spirits, typified by Zé Pelintra, associated with the streets, bars, taverns, gambling, and opportunities. They are seen as mischievous but also compassionate, reflecting a bohemian lifestyle.

Fragmented spirits of the dead, akin to *larvæ*, lacking clear direction or memory. They feed on passions and emotions and are often associated with 'demonic possessions.' The cult aims to provide an 'abode' for these dislocated dead, allowing them to evolve.

practical_system.description: The practical system outlined in the book for working with Pomba Gira is highly operative and emphasizes establishing a respectful, contractual, and evolving relationship with these spirits. It involves creating consecrated spaces ('tronco' or 'assentamento'), performing specific offerings, utilizing spirit signatures ('pontos riscados'), and invoking through songs ('pontos cantados'). The system encourages self-reflection, honesty, and an understanding of the spirits as tutors for personal growth rather than mere servants. It integrates a complex network of elemental correspondences, lunar phases, and localized spirit geographies ('kingdoms') to facilitate communication and manifestation.
tools: Candles (red, black, white, blue, green, yellow, in specific quantities like 3, 7, 9, 12)
Alcoholic beverages (cachaça, red wine, champagne, whiskey, absinthe, chartreuse, anisette, cider, sweet nut liquors)
Tobacco products (cigars, cigarillos, cigarettes, loose tobacco)

Herbs and oils (olive oil, almond oil, essence of anis, bay laurel, basil, coconut water, rue, ginger, wild saffron, eucalyptus oil, cedar oil, pennyroyal, fennel, nettle, corredeira, Crown of Christ, Abre Caminho, Devil’s Tobacco, Malva, Belladonna, Sete Sangrias, Datura, Convolvulus, Digitalis, Pomba Gira's Blood oil, Mater Dolorosa powder/oil)
Food offerings (nutmegs, star anis, popcorn, cornflour, dendê oil, pork meat, honey, cloves, red peppers, fruit, lime, brown sugar)
Ritual cloths (red silk, velvet, black cloth, red cloth, white cloth)
Chalice, glasses, terracotta plates, wooden tray
Personal items (jewelry, earrings, bracelets, lipstick, clogs, pigeon)
Powders (Black Pemba, white pemba, Congo powder, Untie All powder/Abre Caminho, Efun powder, Love powder, Passion powder)
Ponto (spirit signature), pontos riscados (drawn on cloth/ground/plates)
A consecrated book (Spirit Book) for recording intentions and results
rituals: The Rite of the Dreaming Vessel (for building initial connection and receiving guidance through dreams)
A Crossroad Rite (to pacify spirits, commune, and petition for various outcomes, performed at T-crossroads)
A Working with Maria Padilha to open one’s roads and opportunities (involves pigeon sacrifice, candles, ribbons, offerings at a crossroad)
A working to get rid of bothersome people (using Pomba Gira Rainha das Sete Encruzilhadas, performed in a cemetery, involves candles, cigars, and specific offerings)
A Working in order to awaken passion in someone (using Pomba Gira da Calunga, performed at the oceanshore, involving candles, roses, alcohol, powders, and a shared drink)
A Working with Pomba Gira Cigana to tie a man to you forever (performed at a crossroad with the waxing moon, involves specific personal items, candles, alcohol, and roses)

A Working with Pomba Gira Maria Mulambo to separate a man and his mistress (performed near a dumpster/dirty area with a waning moon, involves candles, cigarillos, roses, popcorn, cornflour, dendê, and cachaça)

A Working with Pomba Gira de Angola for making a man leave your life (performed at the target's door or nearby, involves black candles, ribbons, chicken brains/hearts, castor oil, names on paper, and a key)

relevant_quotes.text: The contents of this book are an honest presentation of the wisdom communicated to me by good people (and some bad people) as well as my own connection with Pomba Gira developed over some fifteen years.
Pomba Gira is largely understood as a black art because it is here that we find the cult of the devil and his wife.
She never judges, but always understands – because she is you – only many lifetimes wiser.
Pomba Gira is the free woman who follows her heart and desire and knows the cost.
Pomba Gira is essentially a legion of the dead.
This is a spirit herd that wants us to achieve a union with the truth which we have hidden in our soul.
The ultimate lesson of Pomba Gira is the respect and understanding of womanhood.
The nature of Pombonjira in the light of this is the serpent of fertility that is made fruitful at the crossroad.

The Western seeker mesmerised by Pomba Gira can engage in these simple steps, keeping in mind that Pomba Gira represents a spiritual legion of great obsessive quality. She is not like the still burning mercurial fire of Exu, she is the sulfur that infests and strangles.

In this book I have decided to take matters much further than I did in Kiumbanda, which was merely a presentation of the cult. My perspective on the cult has matured and I also feel more free in imparting the wisdom which the spirits have given to me, along with good counsel and orientation from other priests and priestesses of the cult.

critical_analysis.relevance: This book provides an invaluable, nuanced, and insider perspective on Quimbanda, moving beyond superficial or prejudiced understandings. It offers a sophisticated synthesis of diverse cultural influences—African, European, and indigenous Brazilian—demonstrating how these traditions coalesce into a dynamic, living magical system. By focusing on Pomba Gira's multifaceted nature, the text elevates her beyond simplistic 'devil's wife' stereotypes, presenting her as a profound archetype of female empowerment, wisdom, and transformative passion. The author's detailed exploration of spirit lineages, kingdoms, herbal correspondences, and practical rituals makes this a highly relevant and essential read for serious occult practitioners and scholars seeking to understand syncretic magical systems and the often-misunderstood chthonic feminine principle.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The primary target audience includes advanced practitioners of Quimbanda, Umbanda, and other Afro-Brazilian religions, as well as scholars of comparative religion, esotericism, and occultism. It is also highly relevant for magicians interested in chthonic deities, ancestral veneration, spirit pacts, and the integration of diverse magical currents. The technical depth and explicit warnings against immature or selfish approaches indicate it is for those committed to serious magical work and personal transformation, rather than casual dabblers seeking quick fixes.
